												TLDR: half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥cash-in with no redeeming qualities, 1/10, do not buy, Codemasters should be ashamed.I really don't understand how Codemasters managed to screw this one up.Sure, they definitely indulge in milking old franchises (Worms, anyone?), but this game claims to be "based" on Colin McRae Rally 2.0. CMR 2 was/is an AMAZING game, a benchmark for rally games at its time that has aged exceptionally well. How hard could it possibly be? Take that game, port it to a modern engine, maybe nix a car or two and replace decals if you can't get hold of the same licensing deals, and you've got a great game, done!But no...This game manages to be so basic, so stripped down, that it barely even qualifies as a racing game, let alone something that should be mentioned in the same breath as CMR 2.Cars: CMR 2 had over 20 different cars. This game has 4. Yes, four.Courses: CMR 2 had 8 countries/courses. This game has 3. Yes, three... To make things worse, the Australia and Greece courses are basically the same gravel track. The Corsica Course is 100% tarmac. That's it. All races are in daylight, no rain. Compare that to CMR 2, where you had rain stages, night stages, snow courses, mud courses, hardpack and loose gravel courses, etc...Controls/physics: Pretty much any jump will send you into a barrel roll. There's a glitch that appears pretty often where while climbing, the car will suddenly "snag" onto the track like it's a piece of fabric, and lose all momentum. Wonder how many hours has been put into playtesting...More problems:- The cockpit view. MY GOD. You'll have to see this one for yourself... I'm dead serious, the Sega Daytona USA arcade machines had more detailed cockpit graphics! CMR 2 for PC came out in 2000 and it had a fully detailed cockpit for each car, what the hell happened here?- If you look at actual PC (not console) screenshots of CMR 2, this game does not look better in any regard, it actually looks worse... much worse. Much worse than a game from 2000...- Absolutely no pre-race tuning, which was a major part of CMR 2 and was pretty much obligatory to get good times at courses. But I guess it wouldn't be neccessary in a game like this anyway, where the courses are as varied as peas in a can.- At this point mentioning the lack of replays, additional game modes etc is pointless. This game would still be a steaming turd, with or without more content.Multiplayer: nope.Controller support: if you have anything more exotic than a 360 pad, you're out of luck as there are no remapping options.Please, DON'T repeat my mistake and buy this.

												(Traducción al español abajo) How to drown a good game into disgrace.Having the original Colin McRae Rally 2.0 since it came out, all I expected was to be able to play it fully in my actual machine without learning rocket science. Well, I have to recognize that has been achieved. You can play it... at least the parts you can...Megabazillion tracks... errr nope: The original game brings us 9 countries, (Kenia, Finland, UK, Sweden, Australia, Japan, Corsica, Greece and Italy) each with twelve stages. This rip only brings Australia, Corsica and Italy. By now, The game duration's been cut to a third.Megabazillion rally cars... errr neither: The original game places us behind the wheel of 24 rally cars, counting WRC, B group and various paint schemes. Here there are ONLY FOUR STINKY CARS. Content reduced to a fifth.Then, the controls. I'll agree Colin McRae wasn't the most realistic rally game in history (we have RBR for that), but at least you can figure out what is driving a WRC. Here, the controls are almost random. The car cuts gas in the middle of a straight without any reason at all, and the turns are divided into two: you did it or you didn't (There's no way to negotiate a drift)... Basically, I found out that I can't drive the car as I want (as in the original), but instead I have to learn how the game wants me to drive it.And then, the graphics... well, even worse than the original (the internal view is worth a shot, don't miss it), plus the scenary has been cut to a size that looks more like you're playing Gran Turismo 1.In a nutshell, don't set your hopes any high: It's an awful port, ripped everywhere, and almost unplayable.(Traducción al español) Como desgraciar un buen juego:Teniendo el Colin McRae Rally 2.0 original de la época, lo que esperaba era poder jugarlo completo en el PC que tengo ahora sin tener que andar haciendo experimentos. Bueno, hay que reconocer que eso si se ha logrado, Jugarse, se puede jugar. Lo que se puede jugar...Pistas a go-go... pues nó: El juego original nos permitía correr por Kenia, Finlandia, UK, Suecia, Australia, Japón, Corcega, Grecia e italia. Este rip no trae mas que Australia, Corcega y Grecia. De momento, la duración del juego se ha reducido una tercera parte. Coches de rally a go-go... pues tampoco: El juego original nos pone a los mandos de 24 coches, entre WRC, Grupo B y esquemas de pintura variados. Aquí no hay mas que CUATRO APESTOSOS COCHES. El contenido se reduce a una quinta parte.Luego ya está la cosa de los controles. De acuerdo que Colin McRae no era el juego de rallies mas realista de la historia (para eso está el RBR), pero por lo menos te podías hacer una idea. Aquí los controles son prácticamente aleatorios. El coche deja de acelerar de forma incomprensible en medio de una recta, los giros son una de dos: o entras o no entras (no hay posibilidad de negociar un derrape)... En resumen: me he encontrado con que, en lugar de conducir como yo quiero, tengo que aprender a conducir como el juego quiere.Y los gráficos... pues muy justitos. Comparados con el original son incluso peores (la vista interna del coche es digna de ver), y encima han restado profundidad al escenario de una manera que parece que estés jugando en gran turismo 1.En resumidas cuentas, no te hagas ilusiones: Es un port horroroso, recortado por todas partes, y prácticamente injugable.

												Colin McRae RallyYou hear that name and instantly awesome true Rally experiences come to mind. Harsh terrain, realistic and believable damage to your car as you make stupid mistakes, and a fairly competitive AI that makes it a nice challenge all-in-all.That isn't this game. This game is a mobile port. It isn't (at all) what it tries to advertise itself as. Handling is simplified, damage is merely cosmetic at best, the terrain looks horrible. Remastered is a term many low-resolution games use these days to try and bring these experiences to the modern PC, but Colin McRae Rally doesn't manage to do any of it.It lacks features that previous games in the series. You can't customize your car's behavior before a stage. Repairs are fairly unneeded as they don't impact gameplay, and fixing the "engine" costs the same amount of time as fixing the "suspension" or "wheels".There isn't much else to say. This game was trading on good memories of the Colin McRae series and it's just a cash grab. It's lame, it doesn't feel like a rally game, and overall it's a perfect example of what is happening to Steam's storefront where publishers and developers have no shame about what they try to do with their advertising.

												Like many others, I bought this game expecting a re-released version of the original with some graphics updates and without the hassle of getting an old copy to run on modern hardware. This is not that game.What we have instead is a stripped-down version with less cars, fewer stages and fewer set-up/repair options which was previously released for mobile devices. Don't be under any illusions  - you're paying to play the mobile version with better controls on a bigger screen.In fairness to Codemasters, this is at least a competent driving game. The cars handle at least as well as in the original, with noticeable changes between surfaces. Car damage does affect performance, but the scaled-back repair interface takes away most of the decisions in choosing what to fix between stages. There are only four cars available to drive (three of which must be unlocked by completing events), but they recreated as well as possible in the engine.Ultimately though, I can't recommend this. It may only be £4.99, but that still feels expensive for a cut-down version of a ten-year-old game. You would be better-off spending your money on a copy of the original on ebay and taking the time to get it working

												Well where to begin with this game, I purchased it on the basis that I was going to re-live my childhood memories and play a game that got me addicted to the racing genre, my first race I'm thinking "oh this is cool" but then it is downhill from there. I start the career mode, struggling to figure out how to increase the difficulty, no you can't the "championship" is split up into several championships, where the AI starts off super easy in the first and then gets progressively harder towards the last championships. To add even more insult the first three championships are just based on their respective countries, i.e. Australia is the first championship and Greece is the second. Then they will "Mix" it up a bit and add a championship with all three countries stating "it’s time to test your skill on more difficult changing terrains!" no all they did was make the AI slightly more difficult to beat. Where the AI is concerned it is clear that for each championship they just have a set time to beat which obviously gets harder as you move onto the next championship. Secondly they start the race at 40MPH (so during the later championships you are just playing catch-up) and clearly do not suffer from car damage and hairpin turns, because from start to finish their progress bar moves at the same speed. Next is the damage system! I crash into a tree full on and my car is fully repaired for the next set of races, I cut a few corners and I have no time to repair my car properly resulting into the next two races being a challenge to stop the car from blowing up. Last the sound is♥♥♥♥♥♥ I constantly hear screeching as if I’m sliding on tarmac even if I am playing on a DIRT road, when wearing a headset it will give you a right bloody headache. Codemasters, can you just tell us what the AI target time is on the last championship? If I know then I won’t need to keep on this repetitive ride of going through the same championship over and over and over again, I can just do a time trial. It’s a good thing that this was marketed as "based on" and not a remake, otherwise I would of had a refund, the only way this would be worth the money is if Codemasters threw in the original CMR 2.0 and give us the rest of the game! Where the funk are the other countries? Only three!. The game does have its plus points though, it works well with an Xbox 360 pad and if you handbrake around a bend you get the satisfying sound of the handbrake clicking!

If you buy it and try it, you're getting a useful insight into mobile gaming ported to PC. You're also getting one of a few sparse rally games available for PC these days, and for that, it does hold some value. Just make sure you buy it cheap!I had already bought this on Android and it didn't last long before I deleted it. In hindsight I do wonder if I'd merely missed a config screen allowing you to adjust sensitivity, and in the case of PC, dead zone too.  For my first couple of goes on PC, it was horrible with a 50% deadzone meter and maximum sensitivity. The car would barely turn for most of the stick's travel, then suddeny lurch, makign it twitchy an unresponsive at the same time. Wholly unpleasant. However, step the deadzone down to a few notches off minimum, and reduce the sensitivity to about 35% and it's a different animal; it feels to control much better.There are still issues mind... such as the controller being useless in some menu screens so that you can't actually select the Proceed button; or when up becomes down and vice versa.Once or twice too when driving what appeared to be a rock and incident free stretch of track, the car would flip like it'd hit a big rock, causing confusion and delay as you roll the car and often end up facing the wrong way.If I was to rate this game out of 10, I'd go for a 6. Which kind of puts it just above average and worth a go. Though I cannot stress enough: ONLY IF IT IS CHEAP.

												Ok, where to begin. I suppose I should mention before anything that this is purely a mobile port taken straight off the app store and shoved into Steam for what I can only assume is a quick bit of money making. The price itself isn't all that bad and if you don't have an iPhone/iPod etc. and you want to play this then fine, but go into it with the certainty that it is a mobile port, the feel and style of the original seemingly lost to the pages of gaming history. To get the full experience you'll need to play through championships to unlock other cars/rally's etc. Not a bad mechanic in itself but this game makes it feel like such a chore. First the AI is humorously slow, on my very first attempt i beat them by a minute and a half (and while I may be mistaken I couldn't for the life of me find any option to up the difficulty). Secondly there is no sense of speed while driving, I remember the original leaving me on the edge of my seat, sweating trying to work out what just happened. This just left me feeling like I was stuck in traffic during a long drive home after an exhaustingly long day of work. Now it is perhaps worth noting that my experience and therefore memory of the original may have been skewed by a 6 year olds sense of wonder and far too many Smarties, but I am not quite yet senile so I doubt it is that skewed.It has some positives, like the version I played on an iPod I was impressed by the audio, each time I passed some fans I got a little kick out of the cheers and sounds of horns but alas this kick fades way before I reach the next cluster of my adoring groupies. The handling is average for a mobile so as far as you approach the game expecting that it’s not too much of an issue, though I still feel like I have more chance of power sliding driving at 40 KM/H in that traffic I mentioned (I feel like the game has assists enabled but no way to turn them off…).And that I feel is as good as any point to leave this review on, what is a pretty good mobile game somewhat unsurprisingly makes an entirely dull PC game. Good day folks4/10

												Colin McRae Rally (2014) would have been a somewhat acceptable rally game in 1996. Graphics might have been decent in early 2000s. Like your car attempting to do an aileron roll for no apparent reason, or being stopped by an invisible obstacle when landing. Though I would say that the game engine has trouble not just with jumps, but with pretty much everything related to driving. Controls are unresponsive and most of the time playing feels like you are driving a brick around. A somewhat weirdly behaving brick.And I absolutely "love" the fact that most of the objects you see on the road are completely static, which means that either they are sprites and you go through them without any physical reaction from either the car or the object, or they seem to weigh couple of metric tons regardless of size or material, stopping the car instantly. That is so 1990s. I guess you could call that retro.Also the amount of content is minimal with just few different rallies, and there is no replay value at all. Really.Very much NOT recommended.

It is simply a port of the mobile version, generously referred to as a "Reboot".Expect: Bare-bones graphics, dismal damage engine that is somehow worse than the orignal CMR on PS1, forward-facing sprites, indestructible shrubbery (Robert the Shrubber would be proud), a draw distance that gives the impression that somebody is physically drawing the terrain slowly with a blunt pencil, handling that makes you think that you are in fact driving on retextured damp tarmac, A bad taste in your mouth as the money leaves your account, Nicky Grist.DO NOT EXPECT: Fun, a wide variety of cars/locales (FOUR, that's right FOUR cars and FOUR countries...), HD Graphics, a game worthy of the name, a feeling of accomplishment, willingness to continue playing past ten minutes.Do not treat this title as a true PC release, as the description and media samples on the store page try so hard to portray, but as what it is; a port of a mobile game that wasn't even that spectacular as a mobile game. The four cars are the Ford Focus, Subaru Impreza, the classic Lancia Stratos and the Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution VI. The sound is as important for me as the visuals and if you are a racing fan you will want to have those crazy sound engines screaming for the next shift but once again you can’t expect such thing in this game, which is fine for a mobile port but insufficient for a PC game.In the end I played the game and got most of it, however there is not much to see and do which makes you search for better alternatives. The final line from the Store description ends with a bang but I’m afraid to be a really misleading sentence. It says “The Classic Rally Experience Races on PC and Mac” and I couldn’t agree less. Posted: December 27, 2015
												For some reason, people believes this is a port of the old CMR games from the ps1 days, and later on pc. Well, this is not.I have all of them and, even though I never liked their handling model, this is even worse and the only things in common are the name and some assets.It can't have the same gameplay anyway, since this one uses a different engine, Unity, which is also partly what makes this game so bad.The performance of this game, compared to the graphics, are terrible. It runs just fine in my system, but DiRT2 and 3 at Ultra runs even better here, reaching solid 60fps at 1080p, while this one has worse graphics than CMR 2.0 and runs as badly as the last Batman game.Then there's the "physics", if so can be called, that are so unrealistic that gives the game a much higher difficulty level than what's supposed to have. They could have opted for the arcade handling model of the CMR series, but instead tried to make something just too big for this terrible engine, and it ended up becoming one of the worst racing games of all times, on par with Team6 titles.Controls? People, again, believes this supports gamepads and so "you can control it better than on the smartphone": nope.Although it does support gamepads, the controls are not analog, meaning that the analog sticks will act as digital sticks, which adds problems to the already terrible handling.That's at least what happens to me with the 2 different gamepads I own, and to many other people that can actually understand how analog handling feels like. If it only works for some specific gamepad model is beyond my knowledge, but since Unity has many problems with input devices, it might as well be.There's a load of other little and big problems with this game, such as a terrible menu, terrible configuration screen, basically no graphics options, static tracks and backgrounds, no replays, bland and dated graphics, recycled music from CMR 3 (from what I remember)...I can't really find a single positive thing to say about this game. I got it from the Codemasters bundle and I thank myself for not having spent even 1 euro on this title alone, because it doesn't matter how cheap you can buy it at, it's not worth the time it will make you waste.If you think this could be a nice time waster or a little arcade racer to spend some time on between more serious games, well that's a mistake: the terrible handling and bad pad support makes racing artificially too hard to be enjoyable, and I'd like to see how many of the positive reviewers actually could, or wanted to, complete the game.

Game as in play for 10 minutes or play for an hour.  You don't have to wait an age for it to load, or endure the latest in bad, loud synthetic music, or consult a manual and a physicist on car set up. I have never driven a 4WD but I have driven plenty of 2WDs on very bad surfaces and when I unlocked the Lancia Stratos I finally was driving a car that behaved how I remember cars behaving, including the sudden total and catastrophic loss of all control when you mess up!I bought this on a nostalgia trip when it was offered on Humble Bundle and it's now the game I've played the most hours on Steam.If you're looking for a sim or some kind of pseudo reality and hours of tinkering and stats and so on then look elsewhere. 												Colin McRae Rally is an arcade-style offroad racing game, where you can drive different offroad racers in a variety of circuits and tournaments. Now, I compare all racing games to Gran Turismo 2, which is in my humble opinion, the best racing sim I have ever played. It reminds me of the arcade play of Gran Turismo 2, where you could drive cars like the Lancer Evo on dirt tracks, against a second player or versus computer drivers; However, with Colin McRae Rally, you are going up against computer players times, rather than the actual cars on the track. I think this takes away from the realism of the game, because you don't have other drivers as obstacles to conquer and overcome, it's all about time instead. Visually, the game is so-so, but the cars are pretty detailed. There doesn't appear to be a lot of customization. In all, I wasn't overly impressed with the game, though it isn't exactly a dumpster fire either. It skates by, but there are other racing games out there which would be better.

												SHORT VERSION: This is a very lean game. Don't get me wrong. It's not a BAD game, but it isn't stellar. Unfortunately you don't see your oponnents' cars. Each stage offers a different layout, but to advance to a different area, you have to play stages in the same area like 10 times. I got bored looking at the same environment and playing alone without AI cars.Controls feel just like the cars in the DiRT series, which is good. Your car becomes damaged if you bump into debris and trees. After like 2 races, you're given an option to make a limited number of repairs. With the limited "repair time" you must strategically choose which parts of the car you want to repair.Because of the slow progression through the game (it takes forever to see the different environments), and innability to see opponent cars or race alongside opponents, I cannot recommend this game at this price point. There are far better and fully fleshed-out games that can be purchased for about $5 which are much more fun.

												I've seen a bunch of negative reviews for this game... I do not know if you have VERY poorly running PCs, a version of Windows that runs this badly, or got a snagged file or three in your downloads, but this game looks pretty awesome for what it is, has zero popup, & zero drawin EVER... (something those retro games the negative reviews say this game is not like, but this is far superior to in all the ways that I care about) Do yourself a favor, & set the launchers' graphics to low, but the highest rez possible, high has so much blurring that it not only eats framerate, it looks awful, & I got the feeling that I needed glasses all of the sudden on high, yeah it's THAT blurry, on low the textures look okay enough, & as I said there's no visual artifacts like stuff suddenly popping into the distant view, or texture drawins... As for the handling? Well if you fancy yourself as a hip Rallycross player, turn sensitivity down (unless it's too low straight off, Mine defaulted max), & turn the deadzone ALL the way down... this even makes the cars pull to the side a tiny bit when they shift gears, JUST like cars do on real loose surfaces like gravel/sand. If you fancy yourself as a casual rally player leave sensitivity maxed, & put deadzone 1, or 2 from the lowest setting, this negates the cars pulling to the side when they shift (except in the VERY odd circulstance when you're shifting, & jumping/cresting in 1st-3rd gears, & when that does happen don't hit a tree)If you aren't quite sure exactly what the meaning of the word fancy is... go play NFS yah Yankee! No seriously then you can turn deadzone up really high, which makes the game play/run so smoooth, it almost looks like it's getting a better framerate (the camera is just jerking about less).The tracks in the game all play/look JUST like real rally tracks should (yes up very close SOME of the many kinds of trees, & about 1/2 of the bushes seem to have fuzzy textures (on low, I don't play on high it gave Me motion sickness!), but you spend 99% of your time near the middle of the road, & in high rez that looks pretty darn good, & no popins (Marry?), the turns/hills/etc. are done VERY well (the 1st Championship is VERY easy, straight, & even bland looking tracks, keep playing m'kaaaaaay)The physics in the game? I dunno if peoples Phys-X/Active-X is flarmed up, or they have other issues, but they're dead on except for the fact that the car pivots on an axis like a top, but devs do this because they may look odd from a 3rd person view, from inside the car [more on that...] it "feels" more like a car traversing a loosly surfaced plane. so if you use 2 of the 3 views you'll prob have zero objections to the physics, from the follow the car view it looks pretty artificial turning, drifting etc. {*note to devs* A tighter tail camera clears this up a bit} The game has 3 views... the follow the car view, which is like any other game has, the hood view (bonnet) which lots of even modern games don't bother drawing the dang hood on, this does, & it damages in real time, & the inside car view (cockpit), which is like other games except this oddly has the body of the driver, & steering wheel gone, so it feels a little wierd at 1st, but works well, & once you start focusing on the road/navigator... Myself as with almost all racing games am very happy with this games hood viewI haven't beaten the game yet, so I cannot speak to bugs/glitches in later cars/tracks, but with like 28% unlocked (2 cars, & bunch'a tracks/variations) I haven't experienced any launch/play/control glitches Myself.I also think those people surely must not have actually spent much time playing 1st gen Rally games, or even PS1 Colin McRae, because everything in this game is superior to that game for sure. No splitscreen, no multiplayer, boo hooooooo! Then you hotseat with your friends, taking turns, & noting the times... That's how We did it on LOTS of older games that lacked even splitscreen, so the store claiming this to be retro goodness is 100% correct! (No sorry no demo derby, tag, soccer, or any of the other goofy modes you guys are spoiled with now in other recent rally games)If you have tons of cash, a monster PC, & want the worlds bestest rally experience, then Steam has about 5 better ones, BUT if you're stuck using a slow/cruddy PC like I am (for awhile *sigh*), & Like rally games, or racing in general... $7 bucks ain't to much to ask, & if it's on sale? (I just got Mine for like $1.60 I think) then it's well worth it!Note I'm using Windows 8.1 which has trouble running some stuff, AND a very slow, cheap laptop... if My PC will run this game, yours should too! Using X360 for Win pad (works great)

												If you want a nostalgic rally game, or something to fill in time between DiRT releases, this is defintely a good buy. Otherwise, don't buy it and you might as well stop reading here.As a whole game, it barely stands up with a few glitches in places, and some very repetitive rally stages (I've only found there to be 3 different countries so far). But the experience from this game is more of a reason to buy it. Essentially it feels like the rally games from 10 years ago (partly because it is) but the touch-ups in the remake allow it to feel and look how it does in your memory. This game does what it sets out to perfectly, it lets you relive the old games, without too many of the hassles involved in installing and setting up to work with controllers.As for the actual gameplay, the difficulty level is fairly easy and all the competitors times are pre-determined. The stage progress bar up the top (straight from the old rally games) bears no reference to whats happening on the track for your competitors, and only shows average speed of the lead CPU (Colin Mcrae in every race). When driving, you get the familar pace notes, although they are mostly accurate, relying on them too heavily will cause an accident. Things like sudden hairpins, jumps immediately before corners, and the pace notes only being 30-70m ahead of you make for some very reaction oriented driving (especially in Australia...). Damage is taken fairly easily in the cars, with even crash free stages short causing quite severe damage by the time you get in for repairs, making the 30 minutes for repairs quite strategic. When you crash (you will), the damage to power and suspension is the most noticeable, followed by the wheels, making you have to dynamically change driving styles mid-race (momentum is key with a ruined engine.) If you're expecting a fully fledged game, that will give you an engaging storyline, or even a new experience, don't buy this game. If you're after a relaxed drive down memory lane, and this game is on sale, I highly recommend it. Pros - Takes you back to the rally games of ten years ago. Works flawlessly with Xbox 360 Controller.More emphasis on better driving, rather than speed.Damage and repairs is a nice change.Cons - Invisible walls just of the edge of the track in some places.Pace notes not always accurate or timely. I crashed in the middle of the road, into the road at one point. Rolling the car doesn't result in immediate car reset. Not much variety in rally stages.

												While this game is nothing to rave about, I definitely don't really agree with all of the negative reviews it has received. I've clocked about 5 hours of play time at the time of writing this, and I have three of the four cars unlocked, and only two more championships until I "finish" the game. This game may not be able to hold it's ground against many of the modern, more in-depth console/PC racing titles out there, but for the few bucks this game costs, it's definitely not a horrible game. If you're looking for a cheap, quick, simple, decently fun rally game, Colin McRae Rally is definitely worth a quick look. 3/5

I've clocked about 5 hours of play time at the time of writing this, and I have three of the four cars unlocked, and only two more championships until I "finish" the game. This game may not be able to hold it's ground against many of the modern, more in-depth console/PC racing titles out there, but for the few bucks this game costs, it's definitely not a horrible game. If you're looking for a cheap, quick, simple, decently fun rally game, Colin McRae Rally is definitely worth a quick look. 3/5

												I've played Skyrim, Magicka and Shadow of Mordor. I've read Harry Potter, Lord of the Rings and His Dark Materials. And yet this game remains the most magical experience I have ever had with anything ever. Only in this game are the rules of reality bent to a point where cars will roll over of their own accord, without you even telling them to (that's one step better than dogs!!1!). Only in this does 4 cars constitute a game (yep you read that right 4 whole cars omg wow ikr), and only in this game do textures like this constitute and I quote from the game description "beautiful challenging environments". I live in Australia and I can confirm that while we have roads as wide as the ones included in this game in Australia, they also happen to be OUR HIGHWAYS. This game was released on PC on 31st July 2014. THERE ARE WALLS TEXTURED WITH TREES AS THE EDGES OF THE LEVEL. THE TREES ARE 2D SPRITES. IN 2014. Another little happy magical addition to this overwhelmingly lovely experience of a videogame is the so called "handling model" which I'm fairly sure is based loosely off a shopping trolley they found in the Codemasters parking lot because the cars handle with all the predictability and elegance of a wet lettuce. For example let me talk a bit about jumps. When a car goes over a hill in a road, if it is going fast enough and the hill is steep enough, that car may leave the ground for a period of time in what we refer to as a "jump". Under no circumstances (other than the ones in this game obviously) do the laws of physics stop applying and we switch to moon gravity just because the co-driver decided to call that there was a jump, Such that you can be doing 60mph and COMPLETELY BARREL ROLL THE CAR OFF A FLAT JUMP. If you are looking for a realistic, enjoyable remake of the original Colin McRae Rally (which was a masterpiece), I suggest you go and watch paint dry. It'll probably be more exhilarating, and at least it won't crash between levels.

												This game is such a poor excuse for a remaster and a release in general. It's a remaster of Colin McRae Rally 2.0 (still don't understand why is it called just Colin McRae Rally instead of Colin McRae Rally 2.0 Remastered), but it lacks more than half of the content from the original game. You get to choose from only 4 cars (Ford Focus, Subaru Impreza, Mitsubishi Lancer and Lancia Stratos), 3 of them you have to unlock. There's only 3 countries (Australia, Greece and Corsica, originaly called France), so you get to race only on three types of surfaces - sand, tarmac and gravel. No mud, no snow, no ice. All the races happen during sunny day, which is the only weather condition in the entire game. No night, no rain, no storm, no snowing, no clouds etc. The game is an arcade just like the original, but the driving model is kinda weird. Almost any bigger jump is almost impossible to land in a higher speed, instead you always crash and roll, because the car behaves like if it was made out of rubber. Besides all that the game is also missing the Arcade mode, there's no multiplayer at all, you can't setup the car and you can repair only four things. The game is a port of a mobile version, so the menus look really simple and as for the graphics (since this is a remaster) it's basically just a resolution upscale with few added effects. And yes, I spent 9.6 hrs on this game, because that's approximately how much it will take you to finish all championships, after that there's no reason to play the game any more.
